title: Vote Casey for GSC!
content: Hi! My name is Casey, and I am a second-year graduate student in Chemistry. I am running for re-election as a Graduate Student Council Councilor this year! It has been an honor to serve on the GSC, and throughout my time this past year I have accomplished goals in advocacy and improving communications with the graduate student body. If re-elected, I hope to continue pursuing initiatives in transportation, spending, communication, and public health.

title: Protect campus from IOF war criminals
content:
Last year, 73% of students voted in favor of a resolution supporting the Boycott, Divestment, and Sanctions (BDS) movement. Despite this overwhelming mandate, the University administration has failed to take meaningful steps toward divestment. This inaction ignores the findings of the International Court of Justice, which has recognized Israel‚Äôs responsibility for the crime of apartheid, as well as reports from the United Nations, Amnesty International, and Human Rights Watch, which have documented Israel‚Äôs actions in Gaza as constituting genocide. As Israel intensifies its military operations in the West Bank and repeatedly violates ceasefires, we join the global call for accountability and sanctions.

This resolution designates the so-called Israeli Defense Forces (henceforth referred to as the Israeli Occupation Forces, or IOF) as a terrorist entity. The IOF poses a direct threat to our campus community. IOF soldiers have doxxed Stanford students, and at Columbia University, they used chemical weapons (skunk spray) against pro-Palestine protesters, resulting in hospitalizations. Additionally, former IOF soldiers at Columbia have actively campaigned for the deportation of student Mahmoud Khalil. This violence is not new; the IOF emerged from Zionist militias such as the Haganah, Irgun, and Lehi, which terrorized Palestinian and other Arab communities long before 1948. After 1948, the IOF conducted covert operations in Arab nations to intimidate local Jewish populations into supporting the Zionist settler-colonial project. Today, we witness the IOF perpetrating a livestreamed genocide and intentionally starving the people of Gaza.

This resolution amplifies the call for political bodies to sanction Israel, as is already being done to varying degrees by nations worldwide. It also urges campus affiliates in decision-making roles to protect our community from individuals implicated in war crimes. For example, applicants or speakers who served in the IOF beyond the legally mandated conscription period should undergo additional scrutiny to ensure they are not complicit in atrocities. These measures can be modeled, in part, on the Hind Rajab Foundation, which seeks justice for Hind Rajab and all victims of Israel‚Äôs genocidal campaign by holding IOF perpetrators accountable in international and domestic courts.

We call on the University to honor the student mandate, uphold its commitment to people's rights, and take immediate action to sanction those complicit in these atrocities. The time for accountability is now.

content: It was wonderful serving as the Law School representative on the GSC this past year. This year, we were able to introduce more transparency in rent increases and discuss ways to lower rent prices, address immigration concerns prompted by our undocumented student body, and secure more than $50K in event funding for law school organizations and events. I am running for re-election as a Graduate Student Council Councilor this year and would appreciate any thoughts and support.¬†

title: Elena for GSC Councilor: Advocating for Student Needs
content: The start of 2025 has been challenging for graduate students, with grant reductions, hiring freezes, and continued inflation adding to the pressures of academic life. As a master's student and peer academic coach, I‚Äôve seen firsthand how these challenges impact students‚Äô ability to balance research, studies, and personal well-being. If elected, I will advocate for guaranteed funding for PhD students, create new peer mentorship programs to strengthen academic support networks, and foster a stable, supportive, and thriving community. Let‚Äôs work together to make graduate life at Stanford better.

title: Princess for Senate
content:
Hey everyone! My name is Princess Ochweri, and I‚Äôm running to be one of your ASSU senators. I never imagined I‚Äôd be in this position, but like so many of you, I got tired of seeing issues that should never have been problems in the first place. Stanford should be all about the students‚Äîthe heart of this university‚Äîand I believe our voices need to be heard, with real action to follow.

There‚Äôs a lot of work to be done, but here are a few things I‚Äôm deeply passionate about:
1. Protecting student spaces and communities amid DEI rollbacks
2. Improving food quality, consistency, and variety
3. Enhancing campus safety


These are just a few things I care about, but I want to hear from YOU too! As I meet more students, I‚Äôll keep gathering your feedback to shape my work. Let‚Äôs make our voices count!¬†
If you‚Äôre interested, here‚Äôs my platform :)

title: Animal Liberation Now
content:
Industrial animal agriculture perpetuates systemic harm on multiple fronts: it oppresses animals, exacerbates climate change, and exploits vulnerable human populations. As a student body committed to justice, sustainability, and ethical responsibility, we must confront this exploitative industry and advocate for meaningful change. This petition calls for increased awareness, institutional support for transitioning away from animal agriculture, and the integration of animal liberation into our campus‚Äôs sustainability framework.
1. The Oppression of Animals:
Animals raised in industrial agriculture endure unimaginable suffering, confined to inhumane conditions and denied their most basic freedoms. Their resistance to this oppression, as seen in documented cases of animals fleeing slaughterhouses, underscores their inherent desire for life and autonomy. We cannot ignore their plight.
Reference: Cows‚Äô Struggle for Freedom
2. Climate Impact:
Animal agriculture is a leading contributor to greenhouse gas emissions, deforestation, and biodiversity loss. Research shows that a rapid global phaseout of animal agriculture could significantly mitigate climate change, highlighting the urgent need for systemic transformation.
Reference: PLOS Climate Study
3. Exploitation of Vulnerable Workers:
The industry relies heavily on marginalized populations, including incarcerated individuals, undocumented workers, refugees, and people of color, who face dangerous working conditions, physical and psychological harm, and systemic exploitation. These workers are often treated as disposable, with little regard for their well-being.
References:
‚Ä¢ ALDF Report on Worker and Animal Exploitation
‚Ä¢ Human Rights Watch Report on Worker Rights


Our Demands:
In light of these injustices, we call on the student government and university administration to take the following actions:
1. Public Awareness Campaigns:
  ‚Ä¢ Issue a formal statement to the student body and local news outlets acknowledging the interconnected harms of animal agriculture, including animal oppression, climate impact, and worker exploitation.
  ‚Ä¢ Display educational materials in dining halls highlighting the ethical, environmental, and social consequences of industrial animal agriculture.
2. Support for Transitioning Away from Animal Agriculture:
  ‚Ä¢ Provide resources and support for students seeking to adopt plant-based diets.
  ‚Ä¢ Ensure that all dining facilities offer equally attractive, nutritious, and accessible vegan alternatives wherever there are animal products.
  ‚Ä¢ Maintain ongoing dialogue with students to improve the quality and variety of plant-based options.
3. Integration into Sustainability Frameworks:
  ‚Ä¢ Incorporate animal liberation and the quantification of animal exploitation into existing sustainability frameworks and decision-making processes.
  ‚Ä¢ Include the ethical and environmental impacts of animal agriculture in cost-benefit analyses and food procurement policies.


Conclusion:
By taking these steps, our university can demonstrate leadership in addressing the interconnected crises of animal oppression, climate change, and social injustice. Together, we can build a more ethical, sustainable, and compassionate food system that aligns with our values of justice and equity.

We, the undersigned students, call on the student government to recognize this petition as a referendum of student sentiment and to work collaboratively with students, faculty, and administration to implement these changes.

title: For a bigger bang for your buck, vote Hoyoon Song!
content:
Hello everyone!
My name is Hoyoon Song, and I am running to be one of your 15 senators! I am currently a Frosh Council member, where I have had the honor of a lifetime serving my class. But there is more work to do, and the change that Stanford needs must be addressed through ASSU!

Among many issues, one stands out:
We all feel the weight of Stanford‚Äôs costs, whether it's tuition, textbooks, or even grabbing a meal at Tresidder. With a tuition of more than $90K a year, it is hard to imagine paying even more for essential University services; But we do.

For more information, please be sure to check out my platform and follow my instagram (@hoyoonsong_stanford)!

Thank you!

title: Sengthay for Senate
content:
TL;DR: After leading the allocation of millions in grants to over 600 student groups and advocating for marginalized communities as your Appropriations Chair, I've seen firsthand why this fight matters. I'm running again for Senate to continue defending DEI, ensuring equitable funding, and delivering real resources for our communities facing challenges. Sign my petition today to help keep this momentum going.

For the past quarter, I‚Äôve led a team of seven Senators reviewing $8 million in Annual Grant requests from 200+ student groups. We made tough choices, working with a budget of $4.5 million while prioritizing equity and financial responsibility. Amidst all this, I've balanced preparing for my Truman Scholarship interview, surviving ECON 102B, and keeping up as a student.

Serving as Appropriations Chair isn‚Äôt easy‚Äîevery funding decision carries weight. And when executive orders threaten DEI and marginalized students, we need leaders who fight back‚Äîin policy and in practice.

‚ÄúA week ago, I wondered: Should I rerun for Senate? Does this work matter? Then, I got my answer.‚Äù


Financial Officers from the Muslim Student Union (MSU) joined my Office Hours seeking funds for their Ramadan Iftar Dinners in their Joint Annual Grant. Although we couldn't fully fund their request, I fought to ensure they had enough support for this vital community tradition. Working closely with MSU and the Graduate Student Council, we found a fair and fiscally responsible solution.

Days later, as I walked to work at the FLI Student Success Center, I saw a canopy being built in Old Union. I wondered what it was for.

The following week, I passed by again‚Äîthis time, I saw Stanford‚Äôs Muslim community gathered, breaking their fast, sharing a meal, and celebrating their faith with joy.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs when it hit me: This work matters. I have to keep going.‚Äù


Our communities deserve someone who will fight for them‚Äînot just in the fancy rooms where decisions are made, but in the real world, where those decisions turn into impact.

One More Time.
As your Undergraduate Senator, I will continue to fight for a stronger, more equitable Stanford‚Äîone that defends DEI, secures critical funding for student organizations, and fights for those most vulnerable to national political attacks.

To continue this fight, I need your help. Sign my petition today to put me on the ballot and keep pushing for an equitable, inclusive Stanford.

üìå Read my complete platform here: bit.ly/platform-sengthay
üåê Learn more on my website: bit.ly/SengthayforSenate

Thank you for your support. Together, we can build a Stanford that uplifts all of us.

To the Campaign Trail,
David Sengthay (he/they)
Class of 2026: Urban Studies BA Candidate / Public Policy MA Candidate
üíå sengthay@stanford.edu / üîóbio.site/david.sengthay

[Sengthay for Senate (2025)]

title: SPARK
content:
Dear Stanford Class of 2028,
	
Are you ready to ignite your SPARK?

¬†We‚Äôre SPARK, and we're running to be your Class Presidents with a simple promise: to make YOUR voice heard and to bring real, tangible change to our campus. From floating movie nights at Arrillaga Pool to campouts in Main Quad, from food truck festivals to grade-wide Oval picnics‚Äìwe‚Äôre determined to turn our ideas into events that bring us together. Who says we can't take ‚ÄúCrochella‚Äù campus wide? Who says our formals have to be on campus? With SPARK‚Äì the limits are endless.

	Beyond all, we‚Äôre here to advocate for YOU. With our ‚ÄúPresidents for All Clause,‚Äù every meeting that we have as Presidents, from event planning to budget, is 100% open to all of you, and all people and ideas are welcome! Moreover, we plan to build even stronger connections to the ASSU Senate by taking your questions, complaints, and concerns to them every week. Together, we'll advocate for excused mental health days from classes, fresh fruits in dining halls, and expanding dining dollar options, and more. We‚Äôre not here to run on false promises; we're running to make powerful change! From monthly giveaways based on student event attendance to study nights with midnight breakfast and coffee bars‚Äîwe‚Äôre here to bring our class together by any means possible.

	This campaign is not about us; it's about what we can do together. There's so much more that we have in common than what separates us‚Äì and that's exactly what this campaign is about. If you believe in a campus and representation that listens, that will work tirelessly to bring us together, and will fight for your needs‚Äîthen join the movement, ignite your SPARK.¬†

Vote SPARK‚Äì together we can build a Stanford that works for everyone.

Love,
Anura, Sam, Jasper, Angela, and Asad

title: Petition for The "Bunching" Rule: Demanding a Fairer Final Exam Schedule
content:
My neck started to hurt. My eyes lost focus; medically speaking I might have refractive errors. On the same day, I took three final exams ‚Äî nine hours in total.¬†
This past quarter I enrolled in two math and physics courses to fulfill my major requirements. However, all three of them fall into one single day. Not just I, people in my class who had similar issues talked with their instructors and none were willing to accommodate. That is why I am petitioning for¬† a change in our final exam scheduling process that grants students rights to reschedule their final exams if they exceed 6 hours or two consecutive exams in a single day.¬†
Why should we do so? Researchers at Des Moines University have shown that students performed worse in back-to-back exams with only a 15-minute break than those in spaced-out exams (research paper here). A 15-minute break between exams is exactly what I had. This is scientifically proven to be an effective method to assess students‚Äô academic ability. Moreover, this does not even account for the fact that some candidates have to walk to the other side of the campus.¬† I could not even get lunch between my first and second exams. It is preposterous that we do not even have a chance to eat, when we are supposed to be supported in taking the exams.¬† [Figure 1: Stanford Winter Final Exam Schedule]
I am proposing The "Bunching" Rule, which has been implemented across different college campuses in the United States. Bowdoin College, a liberal arts college in Maine rules that ‚Äústudents with three or more final exams in two consecutive days may reschedule one for a day mutually agreeable to the student and the instructor.‚Äù In the University of Colorado, Boulder, they have a similar policy that ‚ÄúWhen students have three or more final examinations on the same day, they are entitled to arrange an alternative examination time for the last exam or exams scheduled on that day.‚Äù University at Buffalo in New York even defines a final exam conflict as ‚ÄúThree or more final exams scheduled on the same day.‚Äù Makes sense! The Wake Forest College Faculty in North Carolina already established a policy back in 2010 that ‚ÄúStudents should have no more than two exams in a 24-hour period.¬† They should be allowed to reschedule exams in excess of two in a 24-hour period.‚Äù In University of Nebraska-Lincoln, they have a policy that mandates faculty to accommodate students, ‚ÄúThe instructor(s) of the third and subsequent final examination is (are) then obligated to provide an alternative final examination time during Final Exam Week.‚Äù¬†
It makes sense to let students rest and perform to their best ability rather than stressing out and intensely working for 9 hours and possibly longer for those who have classes starting at 4:30 any day (that adds up to 12 hours straight testing). How can we expect students to sit in the classroom and head down for 12 hours for the heaviest weighted exam in the quarter?¬†

[Figure 2: Bowdoin Fall 2024 Exam Rotation has two hours gap between each exam]
As such, we are petitioning that the university implement the following changes:¬†
1. Students should not have more than two final exams scheduled on the same day.¬†
2. For the two exams, there should be at least 1 hour apart during non-lunch hours; at least 1 hour and 30 minutes during lunch hours; all the 15 minute gap should not be tolerated.¬†
3. The faculty must ensure that the final exams are in line with the physical and mental well-being of candidates. Students should be able to reschedule the test on a day of the final week that they do not have two or more exams.¬†
4. All conflicted final exams should be rescheduled without permission.

If you experienced similar scheduling issues and want to share your voice, fill out this Google form for testimony. Thank you!

title: PRIME for Presidents
content:
[Alex Acra, Bebel Vieira, Lauren Koong, and Andreas Lorgen]

Senior year is coming ‚Äî and there‚Äôs no excuse to not have it be our PRIME. Over the past three years, we‚Äôve found our place in different corners of campus‚Äîstudent government, academics, social life, the arts, journalism, cultural groups, athletics, and more. Now, it‚Äôs time to bring everyone together for one final, unforgettable year. 

Many of you might not even know what class government actually does. That shouldn‚Äôt be the case. It should be the driving force behind the moments that make this year special, taking Senior Nights, Senior Formal, and graduation to the next level with smart budgeting, thoughtful planning, and unique events shaped by student input that actually reflects our class. 

Beyond the events, this is about creating a senior year that feels different from the rest ‚Äî where everyone, no matter their circles on campus, can come together for things to look forward to and memories to look back on.

We‚Äôre running because we love this place, we care about the people in it, and we‚Äôre committed to putting in the work so that senior year is as special as the people who make up this class.

This is about all of us coming together to make senior year the send-off we deserve.

The best of Stanford is still ahead. 

It‚Äôs PRIME time.¬†

Alex Acra, Bebel Vieira, Lauren Koong, and Andreas Lorgen

title: Results Reform Raihan
content:
Hey, I'm Raihan. I like calico cats, taking photos on the beach, and side-questing. I'm a real person who is tired of the lip service. ¬†

I won't make promises or propose ideas we can't follow through with. And so, here's my platform of tangible things we can hope to accomplish through my term.

1) Crackdown on free speech limitations and amend Stanford's new institutional neutrality policy that states letters of support as taking positions.¬†
2) Ensure transparency in institutional policies and procedures regarding student demonstrations. Protect student speech by clarifying guidelines.¬†
3) Press for proactive communication from the provost to help students understand unpredicted situations like recent funding cuts, etc.¬†
4) Facilitate interactions between students and professors outside of the classroom. Ideally a fund for student-professor coffee chats and "host-your-student" initiatives.¬†
5) Whatever you want. Reach me at @resultsraihan for suggestions, questions, or praise on IG.¬†Looking forward to hearing your feedback.

Results, Reform, Raihan.

title: Laila Ali for Senate
content:
VOTE LAILA ALI FOR SENATE[LAILA for SENATE-5.png]

ABOUT ME:¬†

My name is Laila Ali and I am a first year majoring in Political Science. I went to an under-resourced rural high school where opportunities weren‚Äôt just handed to us‚Äîwe had to create them. I saw the gaps firsthand: the lack of funding, the absence of cultural representation, and the limited resources for students like me. But instead of accepting it, I worked to change it. I organized Culture Day to celebrate diversity, created student-led initiatives and organizations to bring more resources and opportunities to my peers. I know what it‚Äôs like to feel unheard, to see problems and wonder if anyone is going to step up. And I know the power of taking action, of creating change instead of waiting for it. That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm running for Senate. I love the feeling of making a difference‚Äîof turning ideas into real improvements that help people. At Stanford, I see the same need for advocacy, student support, and real change. I want to take the same passion that drove me in high school and use it to make Stanford a place where every student feels supported, valued, and heard.

MY EXPERIENCES:

Gender Equity : Through Stanford Women in Politics, I organized programming events that uplift women‚Äôs voices in policy and governance.
DEI & Cultural Support : Through the SAPling program, I am proposing a bill to support cultural houses and pre-professional orgs, ensuring they are well supported.
FLI Advocacy : As a THRIVE participant, I understand firsthand the importance of mentorship and institutional support for FLI students .¬†
Leadership : At Girls Nation, as one of 2/450 California representatives, I debated policy and gained hands-on legislative experience.
Civic Dialogue : I serve on the Advisory Board for Unify America, bridging political divides and fostering meaningful discussions nationwide.
Environmental Advocacy : I led a 503c nonprofit, the Junior Philanthropists Organization, organizing lobbying efforts & training 200+ youth advocates for environmental policy change.
Legislative Experience : As a legislative intern for the California Assembly, I worked on education policy and student rights, gaining first hand experience in government.

All of these experiences have shaped my ability to collaborate, advocate, and lead. Whether it‚Äôs fighting for FLI students, protecting cultural spaces, or bridging political divides, I know how to work with others to make meaningful change‚Äîand I‚Äôm ready to bring that same dedication to the ASSU Senate.
More information about me & my platform here - https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xNXJJmg7PZbFPWoZ5QwTtKikreAftLl-s4YsIdY0PeQ/edit?usp=sharing¬†

MY PLATFORM:


1. Expand Themed Housing Options
‚Ä¢ Establish a South Asian House and/or a Middle Eastern and North African (MENA) House to provide a supportive community for students from different backgrounds, fostering discussions on history, identity, and shared experiences.
‚Ä¢ Strengthen existing cultural-themed housing, such as Casa Zapata and Ujamaa


2. Protecting Mental Health Initiatives
‚Ä¢ Strengthen funding and institutional support for The Bridge Peer Counseling Center to ensure round-the-clock access to mental health resources.¬†
‚Ä¢ Push for increased mental health service availability
‚Ä¢ Advocate for reduced wait times for CAPS appointments.


3. Advocating for FLI Initiatives
‚Ä¢ As a THRIVER, I am committed to protecting FLI initiatives, ensuring the new pre-orientation program's success.
‚Ä¢ Work toward re-expanding THRIVE & SOAR, providing more students with opportunities to access mentorship, community, and support.¬†


4. Campus Safety
‚Ä¢ Increased campus lighting in poorly lit areas to improve nighttime safety.¬†
‚Ä¢ Expand and improve 5-SURE hours to ensure students have safe, reliable late-night transportation.


5. International Student Support
‚Ä¢ Push for a more organized international student orientation with more communication
‚Ä¢ International peer mentorship program through the Bechtel Center.
‚Ä¢ Push for more cultural events and integration programs that allow international students to connect¬†


As your ASSU Senator, I will fight to strengthen mental health resources, protect FLI initiatives, expand cultural housing, and support international students‚Äîbecause every Cardinal deserves a campus that uplifts them! So VOTE Laila Ali for Senate, lets make change together <3

- Laila Ali
Class of 2028

title: Emma Muller for ASSU Senate!
content:
Hi! My name is Emma Muller, and I am running to be your ASSU Senator!

I am a Frosh and will be majoring in English and Philosophy. On campus, I am on Stanford‚Äôs Ethics Bowl team and a member of the ACLU. Off campus, I am a member of Amnesty USA‚Äôs National Youth Collective, where I have experience passing legislation focused on increasing youth representation in governance.

I have spent the past year as one of the Frosh Council Representatives, working to plan and execute Frosh events. I also co-wrote and presented a bill to pilot a Sophomore Class Council for the Class of 2028, which allowed me to experience the Senate legislative process.

My platform is based on advocating for reform within the ASSU Senate, protecting diversity and advocacy on campus, and developing opportunities for students to express concerns about life at Stanford. Here‚Äôs a breakdown of my platform:

1. Increase ASSU Access and Transparency
  1. Improving Student Access to the ASSU
  2. Increasing Senate Transparency
  3. Involvement with Class Representation
2. Protect Diversity and Advocacy at Stanford
  1. Supporting DEI Programs on Campus
  2. Stand Up to Federal Government Challenges
  3. Defending Student Activists
3. Advocate for Student Life Concerns
  1. Residential and Dining Experience Changes
  2. Academic Engagement and Spaces on Campus


Read more about my platform here: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1U6jf8pxx959_uGOKvQtsRa-rMs05xYy7KilntuHM9ck/edit?tab=t.0

Please feel free to reach out to me at emuller@stanford.edu or @emma_muller06, I would love to hear from you!

Emma <3
[Change is Now Emma Muller for Senate!.jpg]

title: Doing this One Last Time: Leslie Luque√±o for GSE Representative/GSC Representative at Large
content: I said I was actually going to retire from the GSC this year but here I am, running one last time (actually though because I'm graduating next year!). As the most senior member of the GSC (at the ripe age of 26), I am running for re-election in order to continue in my role as Social Chair and GSE representative or GSC Representative-At-Large, positions I have held during my 3 years on the council. As Social Chair, I have been instrumental in bringing new and exciting graduate student activities (like our Night at TopGolf, outings to sports and arts events, etc.) as well as helping maintain our traditional events like Grad Formal. I came into the GSC when we had to rebuild our social life post-campus closure and now, I co-run events that continuously sell out and serve 1000+ graduate students every year. Beyond being social chair, I also am a first-generation-to-college Latina student and am extremely passionate about affordability issues, immigration and diversity advocacy, and educational accessibility. Now as I enter my last year of doctoral study (I promise this time for real), I hope I have the honor of finishing it off like I started, which is with this commitment to create a legacy of social life and activities at Stanford that will live beyond my time on the council. Thank you and I appreciate your support! (also this is me willingly planning Grad Formal for a 4th time so if you need any sign of continued commitment, let it be that one, thanks :)

title: STILL HAMMERTIME!
content:
Re-Elect Jared Hammerstrom for ASSU Senate!

Why I‚Äôm Running Again?
Serving as your ASSU Senator this past year has been an honor. From helping student groups secure funding for incredible events to advocating to keep Bridge Peer Counseling open, I have worked to make Stanford a place where every student can thrive.
My goal has always been simple: to make every student‚Äôs Stanford journey special, whether that means ensuring our campus is safe, making resources more accessible, or creating an environment where student organizations can flourish. I believe in a Stanford where every voice is heard, every idea is supported, and every student feels empowered.

As Deputy Chair of the Appropriations Committee, I have successfully worked to review $8 million in Annual Grant requests from 200+ student groups making sure that organizations across campus receive the funding they need to host events, provide resources, and enrich student life so that all student groups, large and small, have access to the financial support necessary to thrive at Stanford.
As Chair of Administration and Rules, I helped hold our senators accountable in tracking progress and goals to keep our legislative work organized and impactful. ¬†

This year, we‚Äôve made progress, but there‚Äôs still more work to do. That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm running again, because I know I can continue making a difference, and I‚Äôd love the opportunity to keep advocating for you.

Let‚Äôs Keep the Momentum Going!
Vote Jared Hammerstrom for Senate!
Because Stanford still needs HAMMERTIME!

I hope to have the opportunity to continue to advocate for positive change across the university while also fostering community through our GSC events.¬†

title: Replace Class Presidents with Councils‚ÄîMore Voices, More Representation
content:
Class leadership should be about collaboration, not concentration of power.¬†

Right now, we elect class presidents‚Äîjust 4-6 people to represent almost 2,000 of us. But what if we had a system that actually reflected the diversity of our class? Under the current ASSU By-Laws, the role of class presidents is vague, giving them unchecked power over decision-making. They can even appoint their own cabinet members without requiring elections, consolidating leadership into a small, exclusive group. This system isn‚Äôt built for transparency or representation‚Äîit‚Äôs built for maintaining the status quo.

We‚Äôre proposing a petition to replace class presidents with an 18-member council, starting with the Class of 2029 and beyond. It‚Äôs not completely representative of us all, but it‚Äôs still better than the existing system. No changes would affect current classes‚Äô structures, but future classes would have a leadership team that brings in more voices, more perspectives, and more representation. A Council means less power concentrated in just a group of friends and more collaboration to tackle issues that matter to all of us.¬†

If you want a leadership system that truly represents the student body, sign the petition and help make this happen! Stanford thrives on diversity‚Äîso why doesn‚Äôt our class leadership reflect that?

Here‚Äôs our referendum for more details. Contact jchen28@stanford.edu for any questions or suggestions.

Council System Referendum 2025

Together for change,¬†

Emma Muller, Minji Cho, Jacqueline Chen, Misbah Aziz, & Lysez Santos
Frosh Council Representatives, Class of 2028

content:
Dear Friends,
I have served in SGWU leadership for two years, and my sole reason for running for GSC is to strengthen communication between it and our Union. As one of the writers of the graduate worker contract, I helped secure key protections and benefits‚Äîincluding fair wages, work hour limits, and workplace safety. I believe that better coordination will enhance our Union‚Äôs bargaining power, which has historically led to significant improvements in graduate worker quality of life.
I would be honored to have your vote and deeply appreciate the opportunity to continue serving you.
Thank you,
¬†Rory

title: √Åron for GSC
content:
I'm √Åron Ricardo Perez-Lopez, a third-year PhD student in the Computer Science department. I served on the GSC last year as an at-large representative and co-chair. I'm running again for a term as a School of Engineering or at-large representative.

Last year, I worked with university leaders and offices on wide-ranging issues, including: lowering the cost of reserving space for student groups; clarification of various free speech policies and potential changes to the campus disruption policy; preserving institutions with great importance to students on campus, including the Bridge Peer Counseling Center and the annual Thanksgiving dinner for graduate student and their families; developing a common framework and set of guidelines for the many PhD rotational programs on campus; return of evening and late-night transportation options; improvements to campus infrastructure; increasing support for undocumented and international students; and many others.

Recognizing that many of our collective efforts are yet to bear fruit and require continuous fighting and advocacy, I would like to continue working on the above and other issues related to transportation, housing, affordability, and international as well as undocumented student concerns.

I advocate for a holistic approach to all modes of transportation that considers people walking, biking, driving, using mobility devices, public transit, and many others. I would like to continue working with students, staff, and faculty across campus on improvements to pathways, roads, and public transit. These could include separating bicycle and pedestrian traffic in conflict-prone areas, repaving low-quality segments of road, connecting disjoint pieces of bike paths and sidewalks, relocating obstructed bus stops, adding rain shelters, adjusting bus schedules to align with post-Covid commute times, extending Marguerite service hours to late nights and weekends, and exploring new service patterns.

I would like to help in making low-carbon-footprint modes of transportation like biking and public transit more affordable. Initiatives that could help with this include providing free helmets and bike lights, providing cheap and secure bike storage like bike rooms, bike lockers, and bike cages, subsidizing public transit passes (in addition to the GoPass program already available for off-campus grad students), and funding complementary services like airport shuttles. I would also like to help continue GSC's successful free bike repair events.

As an international student, I am also passionate about issues affecting students who are not U.S. citizens or permanent residents. These include expanding informational resources and aid to students who don't (yet) have a specific legal concern or court case, addressing student concerns about the responsiveness and help received from the Bechtel Center, expanding and standardizing internship opportunities via Curricular Practical Training (CPT) for F-1 visa holders, as well as working to make part-time on- and off-campus employment during the academic year possible for more students.

I would like to see R&DE expand programs that can bring more affordable housing options to students, like the EVGR triples program, as well as subsidized off-campus housing that provides affordable apartments that are also located close to off-campus amenities like grocery stores, caf√©s, transit, etc. I would like LBRE to make the new MPS (mail and package) fee optional for students who don't wish to receive packages to their residence and guarantee that receiving USPS flat mail will continue to be perpetually available for free in any residence.

I aim to work with Stanford and the Graduate Workers union to provide equal opportunities for students who are determined to be outside of the bargaining unit as well as to make sure that any issues that are determined to be of an academic nature and hence not covered by the collective bargaining agreement are still addressed by Stanford administration.

At Ca√±ada, I learned that representing student voice means more than just change for us, it means change by us.¬†

As your undergraduate student senator at Stanford, I will continue the practice of change for us, by us through community-building and collaboration across campus.¬†

title: The Rough Draft Initiative
content:
The Rough Draft is an initiative to create an inclusive social hub for all members of the Stanford community by providing a consistent yet dynamic ‚Äúthird space‚Äù that integrates social, cultural, and educational programming, supporting a well-rounded student experience. Through live performances, speaker series, games and trivia, and collaborative events, the Rough Draft will act as a gathering space focused on intentional and social programming, fostering meaningful connections among students, faculty, and a breadth of campus organizations.¬†

The Rough Draft will bridge student groups by curating events aligned with shared interests, enriching the Stanford community fabric. This cross-campus engagement will enhance student collaboration, strengthen social bonds, and contribute to a more vibrant campus community. Additionally, the Rough Draft will provide staffers with education in culinary arts, hospitality, operations, and financial management, equipping students with practical leadership skills in a real-world entrepreneurial setting. Through teamwork and structured class mentorship, the Rough Draft will not only serve as a social and cultural hub but also as a training ground for future leaders.¬†
Initially conceptualized as a student-run pub, the Rough Draught Pub proved to be a transformative addition to Stanford‚Äôs campus life through its successful pop-up events in Fall 2024. These gatherings demonstrated the high demand for a consistent, inclusive, and vibrant social hub for Stanford students. To continue our mission of creating an inclusive social hub, we plan on hosting continuous pop-ups during AY 2025-2026 while we establish permanently.

title: LIFT OFF!!
content:
We‚Äôve done the work. Sophomore Formal had a record number of students in attendance. Open tabs at various coffee establishments on campus to make your finals weeks easier. A class dinner (and wedding cake) purely for novelty and excitement in the name of building a stronger class community.¬†
We‚Äôve always pulled through when it matters.¬†


We‚Äôre returning candidates because being Class President isn‚Äôt just about a title for us‚Äì it‚Äôs an act of service to our Class that we love. We‚Äôre not here to figure things out. The behind the scenes is complicated‚Äîwe already know what works, what doesn‚Äôt, and exactly how to make senior year fun, memorable, and most importantly, yours. We‚Äôve learned a great deal. We‚Äôve planned the events, balanced the budgets, and laid the foundations for new Class traditions.¬†

Things to look forward to this Spring:
A video game tournament (wanna win a PS5?)
Junior Formal (It‚Äôs happening. It‚Äôs in the Spring.)
Class Brunch (dosas and mimosas?)¬†
WE CAN FINALLY GIVE YOU ALCOHOL <3

Things to look forward to Senior Year:¬†
Senior Nights, of course
Alumni referral events and resume workshops to help you secure that full-time offer
More class dinners (and less wedding cakes)
Being appreciated! NICE merch (that you can wear forever), free grad pics with your friends, and a lasting mark on campus
Senior Sunrise
Michelle Obama speaking at graduation
We‚Äôve heard you (especially on Fizz).¬†


Our charge as Class Presidents is to create a Class of 2026 community that goes beyond the friends you‚Äôve already made, and to make Senior year special for each and every member of our class. LIFT is proud to reflect Stanford's diverse student body and will stop at nothing to create a Senior year in which everyone feels celebrated.¬†
We‚Äôve done the work these past three years. Senior year is taking off‚Äîand we want you with us. It‚Äôs time to LIFT OFF!


Love,
LIFT (Yara Elian, Rishi Jain, Gabby Edelin, Pierre Dagsi)
Cabinet (Aili McGregor & Matthew Guck)

title: ANGIE for Senate
content:
Hi, my name is Angie, and I‚Äôm running for Senate to advocate for practical solutions to real problems ‚Äî the kind of changes we can actually see and feel in our daily lives. I believe in noticing what‚Äôs overlooked, listening to what matters, and acting on what‚Äôs possible.

Here are a few key changes I want to push for:
‚ú® Free Tampons & Pads Everywhere ‚ú® ‚Äì Some buildings provide free menstrual products, but many dorms, STEM, and older buildings still charge for them. That‚Äôs unfair and inconsistent. I will push to unify access and remove these hidden costs.

‚ú® Implementing Wellness Days ‚ú® ‚Äì the quarter system is unforgiving, and we need a break sometime. I will advocate for official Wellness Days ‚Äî built-in, no-strings-attached days off ‚Äî so students can recharge without falling behind.

‚ú® Eco-Box Meals To-Go ‚ú® ‚Äì Many campuses already have reusable to-go meal containers, but Stanford doesn‚Äôt. If you have back-to-back classes and no time for the dining hall, you should have the option to check out an Eco-Box, fill it with food, and eat on the go. This reduces waste and improves dining accessibility‚Äîa simple fix for a common problem.

‚ú® Dorm Open House ‚ú® ‚Äì Was I the only one lost filling out the housing application? I propose an event where all students can tour different housing options, ask residents questions, and make informed choices about where they want to live next year.

‚ú® More Late-Night Options: Dining, Transportation, and Gym ‚ú® ‚Äì¬† Let's stop gatekeeping buildings (I'm looking at you CoDa, Y2E2, Gates). Whether you're studying late, coming back from an event, or just need a (healthy) meal past 9 PM, you shouldn‚Äôt have to struggle.¬†
‚ú® Increased Study Spaces & Library Hours ‚ú® ‚Äì Finding a quiet study spot or a group space shouldn‚Äôt feel like a competition. I will advocate for more 24/7 study areas, better reservation systems for group spaces, and dedicated silent-study zones that actually stay silent.

‚ú® Reducing Light Pollution ‚ú® ‚Äì I like stars, but light pollution is consuming them (nights are actually becoming around 10% lighter each year). I will work to add a simple caps on globe light, reducing light pollution.¬†
I‚Äôm a noticer, a listener, a problem-solver, and an outlook stalker ‚Äî and I want to hear from you!

If you have ideas for policies that would improve our campus, please reach out:
¬†üìß angiezha@stanford.edu
üì± Instagram: @angiezha_
Sign this petition and let‚Äôs make Stanford work better for all of us.
Fond regards,
Angie

title: H&T: TROY For Senate!
content:
hey stuzz (stanford huzz).

let‚Äôs cut to the chase. who are we?
H&T. hannah and troy.¬†Hilarious and Tomfoolerous. (something witty).

H&T is a sophomore duo eager to represent YOU! ready to hit the ground running, we have a lengthy list of reforms that‚Äôll serve to improve the lives of all stanford students.

okay, that sounds great but.. what are we all about?

TLDR:

‚òÖ IMPROVE & FUND mental health resources
‚òÜ REFORM student dining experiences
‚òÖ IMPLEMENT safety & accessibility measures
‚òÜ EXPAND transportation options
‚òÖ INCREASE campus affordability
‚òÜ EXPAND academic resources
‚òÖ PROMOTE inclusion and diversity
‚òÜ PROVE that stanford actually loves fun
all this, just for you ;)

want some examples of our policy recommendations?

‚Ä¢ Improve awareness of mental health resources by collaborating with the Vaden Student Health Advisory Committee
‚Ä¢ Provide support through funding for identity-affirming campus organizations to create communities for people of all backgrounds¬†
‚Ä¢ Reform and expand the Student Dining Committee Program to increase student representation and input in R&DE¬†
‚Ä¢ Develop and promote tutoring resources that are accessible and tailored to students with neurodivergent conditions, learning disabilities, and other diverse backgrounds
‚Ä¢ Transfer unused meal swipes into meal plan dollars or additional financial aid
‚Ä¢ Enhance transparency in financial aid award processes to ensure that students have a clear understanding of their financial support


sound interesting?

consider signing our petitions and keep an eye out for updates for our full platform via our socials!

love,
H&T
hannah & troy <3

Our Linktree (check out our full platform!): https://linktr.ee/HannahAndTroy4Senate
Our Instagram: @HannahAndTroy4Senate

title: Vote Viviana!
content:
Hey, my name is Viviana Chuquijajas (she/her)! I am hoping to re-run for Senate next year! Introducing myself a little bit, I am a junior who is serving on the current 26th UGS Senate. I‚Äôm a double major in Comparative Studies in Race & Ethnicity as well as Political Science. I am also a proud daughter of Peruvian immigrants and from indigenous Quechua-Aymara family! ¬†

Using key principles of accessibility, transparency, and visibility, I have used my position as a Senator to connect with and help advocate for the student body. I currently serve as Chair of the Housing & Dining Committee as well as being Deputy Chair of Affordability & Accessibility Committee and Health & Safety Committee. I also participated as a member of the Political Action Committee. During my time on the Senate, I have worked and participated towards campus-wide events and concerns, such as advocating for better support systems for co-ops including better RA stipends and having International Women‚Äôs Day programming. I have pushed for protections of our immigrant population at Stanford, including international and undocumented students. I hope to continue working with student groups and the student population to help advocate and advance their initiatives, concerns, and needs.

Next year, I hope to continue these goals and work towards bigger and better changes for our campus life, including accessibility, safety, inclusivity, and general well- being of student life.¬†

Please consider reading a little bit more about my experiences and platform here! ¬†

Thanks!!¬†
Viviana ü´∂üèΩ

title: Fund Asha for Education
content:
The administration just DENIED the majority of Asha Stanford's annual grant ‚Äî a decision that will directly prevent 150+ students in India from attending school this year. Every $1000 Asha Stanford donates funds a student‚Äôs life (including education, housing, food, & other necessities) for an entire year.

For over three decades, Asha Stanford has been a cornerstone of Stanford's commitment to global education. We are a completely volunteer-driven organization of Stanford students and Bay Area community members who raise $100,000-250,000 annually through cultural philanthropy events, primarily through our signature Holi festival. Our Holi festival is legendary - what started with 300 people on campus has blown up to 10,000+ attendees, raising between $100-250K every year. That money goes directly to schools in India giving kids access to education they'd never get otherwise.

Our current financial situation was misunderstood, and therefore, our annual grant was slashed from $34,000 to $11,000. Running Holi ‚Äî an event completely free for all Stanford students ‚Äî poses a significant cost to Asha. Without the annual grant, we will *not* be able to run Holi this year, neither will we be able to raise $100,000+ to donate to Indian non-profits. This actively abandons the hundreds of students we‚Äôve been supporting for years.

We urge you to sign this petition asking the grant committee to reconsider their decision. Don't let bureaucratic ignorance DESTROY Stanford Holi ‚Äî the event you love ‚Äî and steal the future from underprivileged students who deserve better.

A detailed breakdown of the critical expenses can be found here: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1-zcrkfNXxZu1bbaGKwx2Jk3DONPnNuymZP77FzQ7Ksw/edit?usp=sharing

title: Row house meal plan dollars
content: Petition to give row houses meal plan dollars! With 10 in house meals and 5 swipes a week, the row house meal plan is essentially the same as the 15 meal plan minus dining dollars‚Ä¶ for the exact same cost. The ‚Äùcontinental‚Äù breakfast is very house dependent and is ignored by most.¬†
